narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about all things sustainability including cool facts. Learned about lots of different industries that now appeal to me career wise. Overall, was very insightful.

I developed my technical research ability, numerical aptitude, as well as general knowledge of past, present, and future technologies. I also got the opportunity to develop my presentation skills towards the end of the course

I felt that I came away from the course with more nuanced views on certain hot-button issues surrounding technology and a better understanding of the challenges that we as a society face with regards to these technologies.
I learned more about renewable energy, high speed transportation, computers, and energy generation.
Learned more about recent developments in technology, such as electric cars and power generation, and connected these developments to how they are handled in policy creation.
This course mainly taught me about sustainability and the issues that need to be rectified in order to achieve a 'green' future.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: very interesting material, professor tried to include fun parts like gifts, the presenters were very cool
Weaknesses: some times material was too complex and hard to grasp if you didn't have a good understanding of it

While definitely an interesting and engaging course, it was overall very disorganized and lacked any consistent day-to-day progression. In addition, the homework reflected little of what was being taught in class. No matter how detailed of notes I took in class or the level of effort I put forth, the grades on the problem sets seemed only tangentially dependent on the content that was being taught in class.

A strength of the course is that the material is intrinsically quite interesting because of its great importance for our future. I think one thing that would improve the course would be to implement more structure in terms of what is being discussed. Specifically grouped and separated topics would be an improvement over the slightly jumbled current format in which I felt that some topics were discussed multiple times at wildly different points in the course (the prime example being electrical energy, which was probably discussed 3-4 *separate* times).

The main strengths of this course were definitely the low workload (we only had three problem sets and one midterm the entire semester, which were "open google") and the vast knowledge of Prof. Prober. He knew a lot about everything he lectured about, and since this was a seminar, questions and responses from the class were encouraged and solicited. The main weakness (although this isn't really a weakness if you are good with this topic) is that it was very climate and energy-focused. It felt like AP Environmental Science a lot.
More student-student interaction to increase attentiveness. Classes were all lectures so there was rarely dialogue from students.
The course was a great fit for a small-group seminar. I enjoyed getting to know other students in group projects.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The presentations from others were very good and the homework help sessions were smooth. More in class discussions may make the class more engaging.

I think that a lot of the class was just lecturing and students missed the unique opportunity to create a true seminar environment. I was looking forward to debates and constructive discussions that would complement the course, but those were never included.
Overall, I'm not really sure what could be done to improve a course like this during the pandemic.

In a typical year, this class is chock full of field trips and other activities. This year, this was not the case, and the class was a lecture every day. Finding some way to replace the field trips would have been nice, such as incorporating games or in-class group activities via remote learning that engaged the class.
The use of virtual lecture more sporadically to improve student engagement.

Operating within the boundaries of Zoom is difficult for any class, and it particularly impacts seminar-style courses like this one, which to no small degree rely on spontaneous conversation and questions. That is difficult to do over Zoom. However, the content presented was done in a good way.

I think the fact that we had our videos switched on for the lecture helped with engagement however I think that either periodic quizzes to ensure that students are keeping up with the work would help.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it was interesting and not too challenging for a first year. The professor was very nice.
I would recommend this course to someone interested in the politics surrounding technology or to someone vaguely interested in STEM but with no expertise whatsoever.

Yes, the requirements necessary to earn an A are clearly understandable and achievable. If you want to pay attention to the lectures, you can learn something about modern technology (and some technology policy here and there). This class had people of all science levels, but it was designed so that you don't need any science knowledge or experience at all going in. This was very reminiscent of high school AP Environmental Science at times.

Yes. I learned a great deal about a wide range of technologies that I had perviously very little knowledge about. Great overall primer for any STEM candidate looking to learn about practical technologies.

I would recommend this course as it is a great science course for those that do not want something with a heavy workload. Moreover, the actual course content is interesting and the guest lectures were all very engaging.
